event.desc: Mar Samuelgained distinction in the conflict of persecution. Mar Samuelwent into exile in the district of Claudias where he took up residence in the Convent of the Huts. He related the story of the establishment of theConvent of John Urtayato John of Ephesus. This occurred 536/7 A. Gr. 848

event.desc: Mar Samueldied in 539
Before the Convent of John Urtayawas established there were a collection of huts on the site, named after Mar Afwrsm.
Mar Johnbuilt a hut near the huts ofMar Afwrsmin the year 700

Johnwent about preaching and teaching the Christian faith in UrtayaUrtaye and spoke the language of Urtaye. As such, many believed that John was Urtaya and called him by that name. John was actually Syrian.
John Urtaya's fame spread far and wide, attracting many followers including two excellent scribes from the Convent of Edessa at Amida, Samuel and Jonathan.

event.desc: Anonymi 3675established a monastery in Beth Bar 'rubtha.
Mar Samuel, prior to founding Mar Samuel Convent, visited theConvent of John Urtaya.
Mar Samuelstood on a column for a time before he began to build his convent. Abraham III sent his monks to help Mar Samuel build the convent.
Kawad, King of Persia attacked the City of Amida, slaughtered many people, took captives, and razed the Convent of John Urtayain the year 502/3 A. Gr. 814
The story of Kawad's invasion was related to John of Ephesusyears later when he was a white haired man, living in the monastery at Beth Gubrin.

person.persName: The white-haired man from the monastery at Beth Gubrin

residence.note: Anonymous 3676resided in the monastery at Beth Gubrin.

event.desc: King Kawad's invasion was devastating and drove many away from theConvent of John Urtaya. The white-haired man fled from Amida.
Another old man, named Paul of Arzen, related the history of the Convent of John Urtayato John of Ephesus.
Paul was a monk in theConvent of John Urtayawhen there were 400 monks residing within its walls, and shortly before King Kawad's invasion of Amida.
Because King Kawad's invasion destroyed theConvent of John Urtaya, Paul took up residence in Monastery in Orientals in Edessa.

residence.note: Paulresided in the Convent of the Orientals in Edessa.

event.desc: Pauldied during the second persecution sometime after 536.
TheConvent of John Urtayawas rebuilt after King Kawad's invasion, but on a smaller scale--both in the number of buildings erected and in the number of monks admitted.
Cosmas succeeded Abraham III as head of theConvent of John Urtayaand served during the reign of the Emperor Anastasius.

occupation.note: Cosmaswas an archimandrite of Convent of John Urtaya

event.desc: Cosmasdied
Sergiussucceeded Cosmasas head of theConvent of John Urtaya.

occupation.note: Sergiuswas the archimandrite of the Convent of John Urtaya

event.desc: Sergiusdied in the first persecution in the monastery of Mar Mama
Symy succeeded Sergius Ias the head of theConvent of John Urtayain 522
Symyprophesied many things that came to pass, including his own death three and a half years after assuming the office of archimandrite.
Symydied three and a half years after assuming office in the Convent of the Poplars in 526
The monks of theConvent of John Urtayawho were in exile during the first persecution were allowed to return to their convent and inter Symy's bones there in 530
Abbasucceeded Symyas head of theConvent of John Urtaya.
The Emperor Justinian began his reign in August 1, 527
The persecution was renewed through the descent of Ephraim and all of the convents were expelled in 536.
Abba and Anonymi 3677 went into exile and took up residence in the Convent of the Poplars.

Abraham IVdied and was buried in the monastery.
Sergiusof Amida succeeded Abraham IVas head of theConvent of John Urtaya
Sergiusgained distinction in exile during the persecutions and embraced asceticism and abstinence.
